title: How do you exclude JSHint and CSS Lint?
body:
I want to just use HTMLHint. Is there a configuration where I can exclude JSHint and CSS Lint?

Currently, I am using HTMLHint like this:

```
import HTMLHint from "htmlhint"

const errors = HTMLHint.verify(val, {
    "tag-pair": true,
    "doctype-first": false,
    "tag-self-close": true,
    "doctype-html5": false
})
```

title: Unclosed script tag prevents checking for all other errors
body:
**Describe the bug**
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
- When there is an unclosed script tag, it ignores all other errors/warnings.
**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to 'https://htmlhint.com/'
2. Add an unclosed `<script>` tag
3. Add an illegal tag on the next line like <invalid>
4. Notice that only the unclosed `<script>` tag is reported

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
- It should report both the script and invalid tags

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.
![Screen Shot 2019-10-25 at 9 44 30 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25855866/67576225-28f00e80-f70c-11e9-838b-6af67c3f40a9.png)

title: Should <option> in <datalist> be closed?
body:
I am using HTMLHint in Visual Studio Code (v 1.39 Windows 10) with Mike Kaufman's HTMLHint extension (v 0.6.0) installed.

If I write this code
```html
<datalist id="test">
  <option value="1" label="bad">
  <option value="2" label="good">
</datalist>
```
I get the following error message:
Tag must be paired [</option>] start tag match failed (tag-pair)

If I add the </option> closing tags the message disapears.

The HTMLHint configuration I am using is "tag-pair": true, but looking at the HTML spec
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/form-elements.html#the-option-element
I would say that the closing tag can be omitted.

By the way, if I validate the document in the W3C validator (with or without the closing tags), no error is detected.

Is this a bug? Is it a bug of HTMLHint itself or a bug of the HTMLHint extension?

Thanking you in advance,

title: feature_request(rule): check mixed (unsecured) content
body: ### 1. Summary It would be nice, if would be possible check mixed (unsecured) content locally. ### 2. Argumentation #### 2.1. About Read about [**mixed content**](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Mixed_content?utm_campaign=default&utm_medium=firefox-console-errors&utm_source=mozilla). It not good for `https` sites. #### 2.2. How can an error occur I've a `https` site. I add to it images, videos and so on, which are located on third-party sites. I can't see protocol of third-party site → I've unsecured content on my site. ### 3. Example of expected behavior #### 3.1. Checking process The rule simply should check that there is no `http` in `src` and some other attributes. Example: + :heavy_check_mark: Good: ```html ``` + :x: Bad: ```html ``` Crawlers or localhost will not need. #### 3.2. Attributes list + [**Passive content list**](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Mixed_content?utm_campaign=default&utm_medium=firefox-console-errors&utm_source=mozilla#Mixed_passivedisplay_content) + [**Active content examples**](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Mixed_content?utm_campaign=default&utm_medium=firefox-console-errors&utm_source=mozilla#Mixed_passivedisplay_content) Also, it would be nice to support `data-src` attribute for `img`, [**which is used on plugins for lazy loading**](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/4649). ### 4. Not helped #### 4.1. Web tools I couldn't find, how I can use web-services like these programmatically, in development process: + [**Missing Padlock**](https://www.missingpadlock.com) + [**JitBit SSL Check**](https://www.jitbit.com) #### 4.2. CLI tools I found these tools: + [**check-mixed-content**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/check-mixed-content) + [**https-mixed-content-check**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/https-mixed-content-check) They're not doing what's described in my request. They crawl web-pages and links in them. Pages of my site may be not checked, unlike hundreds pages of third-party web-pages. In addition, domain required for these packages. Files directly or localhost checking doesn't support; I can't use checking in development process; I need push files to hosting. #### 4.3. HTML linters I check my site, use 4 HTML linters ([**The Nu Html Checker, HTML Tidy, htmllint, HTMLHint**](https://kristinita.netlify.com/pages/about-for-developers#Validation-table)) → I couldn't find them the desirable feature. Thanks.

title: False positive for right angle bracket ">"
body:
**Describe the bug** I am not a front-end expert but If I understand correctly, the right angle bracket ">" is not necessary to escape in HTML or XML. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Go to htmlhint.com 2. Paste in some HTML which contains a text with ">" for example` Hello

Hello > World

` The above HTML actually validates with no errors with https://validator.w3.org/ (whereas the unescaped left angle bracket "<" fails validation as expected with w3.org ` Hello

Hello < World

` 3. It complains about the ">" **Expected behavior** It should maybe not complain about unescaped right angle bracket. Info https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7389867/is-it-necessary-to-html-encode-right-angle-brackets

title: Label "for" attribute should match existing id if present
body: The "for" attribute in HTML5 labels when used to reference discrete elements by id could be validated by verifying that an element with said id does actually exist.

title: tag-pair allows optional close tags
body:
**Fixes**: #243 

#### Short description of what this resolves:
it makes tag-pair to allow optional closing tags.
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/syntax.html#optional-tags

title: Transpiling issue with ES5 compatibility
Update CHANGELOG.md
body:
Would be good to update CHANGELOG.md as there have been some releases (https://github.com/htmlhint/HTMLHint/releases) since it was last updated. If maintaining a separate CHANGELOG.md is too much extra work then instead could consider removing the list of changes and instead have a note that says to check https://github.com/htmlhint/HTMLHint/releases.

That is the approach that the Bootstrap 3 GitHub Repo took: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/v3-dev/CHANGELOG.md

title: Rule request: Disallow protocolless URLS
body:
URLs without specifying the protocol are often regarded as an anti-pattern and advised against in the Google HTML Style Guide: https://google.github.io/styleguide/htmlcssguide.html#Protocol

I'd like to request an option in HTMLHint to disallow protocolless URLs, so that I get a warning if I add for example any of these:

`<script src="//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.4.1/jquery.min.js"></script>`
`<link rel="stylesheet" href="//use.fontawesome.com/releases/v5.8.2/css/all.css">`

title: Broken paragraph tag not being noticed
body:
**Describe the bug** A broken paragraph tag followed by another paragraph tag isn't noticed by **HTMLHint**. Also if you have _attr-value-not-empty_ on it says `The attribute [

some text here

A heading here

``` **Expected behavior** An error message about the broken tag. This is with version 0.11.0

title: feat(htmlhint): add raw-ignore-regex option to spec-char-escape rule
body:
- [x] Check the commit's or even all commits' message styles matches our requested structure.
- [x] Check your code additions will fail neither code linting checks nor unit test.

#### Short description of what this resolves:
- Adds a `raw-ignore-regex` option to the `spec-char-escape` rule, to allow dealing with some template languages (e.g. angular.js templates).

#### Notes:
- The `raw-ignore-regex` option needs to be passed as a String, without the common trailing and leading `/`, and thus without modifiers. The regexp is then created via `new RegExp(options['raw-ignore-regex'], 'g');`

#### Configuration Example:
```json
{
  "spec-char-escape": {
    "raw-ignore-regex": "{{.*}}"
  }
}
```

The clutter of these redundant attributes is distracting.

Having to always remind developers about this is wasteful of time.

**Additional context**

Nothing else.

title: docs(rules): usage argumentation
body:
### 1. Summary

It would be nice, if HTMLHint documentation will contain arguments, why HTMLHint users must use specific rules.

### 2. Argumentation

“Must” in `The script tag can not be used in head.`, `Id and class value must meet some rules: underline, dash, hump.` is not argument. The documentation does not show the reasons. Users should know “Why must”?

### 3. Example of expected behavior

As for [**CSSLint**](http://csslint.net/) wiki. Examples:

+ `adjoining-classes` rule use, [**because Internet Explorer 6 doesn't support adjoining classes**](https://github.com/CSSLint/csslint/wiki/Disallow-adjoining-classes)
+ `fallback-colors`, [**because Internet Explorer 8 doesn't support `rgba()` `hsl()` or `hsla()`**](https://github.com/CSSLint/csslint/wiki/Require-fallback-colors)

HTMLHint wiki doesn't contain similar argumentation.

### 4. Specific rules

At first, I want to know argumentation for these rules.

#### 4.1. head-script-disabled

+ [**Link**](https://github.com/htmlhint/HTMLHint/wiki/Head-script-disabled)

[**Most popular Stack Overflow answer**](https://stackoverflow.com/a/24070373/5951529) with 1608 stars at March 2019:

> The current state-of-the-art is to put scripts in the `<head>` tag and use the `async` or `defer` attributes. This allows your scripts to be downloaded asap without blocking your browser.

Script tag must be used in head.

#### 4.2. id-class-value

+ [**Link**](https://github.com/htmlhint/HTMLHint/wiki/Id-class-value)

BEM — [**the most popular CSS methodology**](https://www.edwardrobertson.co.uk/blog/which-is-the-best-css-methodology-/) use underlines **and** dashes both. Example [**from BEM quick-start**](https://en.bem.info/methodology/quick-start/#element):

```html
<!-- `search-form` block -->
<form class="search-form">
    <!-- `input` element in the `search-form` block -->
    <input class="search-form__input">

    <!-- `button` element in the `search-form` block -->
    <button class="search-form__button">Search</button>
</form>
```

Users don't need use underlines **or** dashes.

### 5. Do not offer

Yes, I know, that I can enable/disable/modify specific HTMLHint rules. My question not about it.

Thanks.

title: Add a `--fix` flag to automatically fix lint errors
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
No way to automatically format a HTML file to obey the linting rules. This is especially problematic on large files.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Support a `--fix` flag like other linters such as ESLint.

title: feat(htmlhint): tag-self-close to empty-tag-not-self-closed
body:
**Fixes**: #311 

🚨 Please review the [guidelines for contributing](CONTRIBUTING.md) and our [code of conduct](../CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) to this repository. 🚨
**Please complete these steps and check these boxes (by putting an x inside the brackets) before filing your PR:**

- [ ] Check the commit's or even all commits' message styles matches our requested structure.
- [ ] Check your code additions will fail neither code linting checks nor unit test.

#### Short description of what this resolves:
Added this rule to replace tag-self-close because in HTML5 self-closing tags are optional. If the rule is enabled, empty elements don't need to be closed.

#### Proposed changes:

## -

- I've made changes to the Wiki page: replaced tag-self-close rule to empty-tag-not-self-closed

👍 Thank you!

title: make site with jekyll for htmlhint.io
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, htmlhint.io redirects to the github wiki. For example, the "about" button in the nav bar takes you to https://github.com/htmlhint/HTMLHint/wiki/About 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We want all the markdown documents and information to be on the site!

title: Add alt-require as a default rule
body: **Describe the bug** The rule alt-require is currently not a default rule. However, it should be added to encourage using the alt attribute on all imgs. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. open new html file with default rules 2. does not flag a warning **Expected behavior** We want all imgs to have an alt tag (can be empty) Also requires text areas with href attribute to have alt tag Input tags with type="image" should have alt tag

title: id-class-value being fired by id containing interpolation (angular related)
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
It frustrates me when making interpolated ids on angular. It always fires up `id-class-value`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
It would be nice to have an option to allow `{{variable}}` alongside the already existent configuration.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
maybe adding an option like `allow-interpolated-attr-content` that would activate the above mentioned behaviour

**Additional context**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5878866/54536386-64a14980-496f-11e9-897a-2691df1baa4b.png)

title: Create version of HTMLHint for the browser only
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We want to use HTMLHint in the browser, but there are many dependencies that only seem to be used for the CLI version of HTMLHint.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A new npm package to be published that only includes the one file necessary to run HTMLHint in a browser.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
None.

**Additional context**
We are shipping npm dependencies, and we want to avoid having to do a licensing review for all of the current dependencies.

title: community standards for creating custom HTMLHint rules
body: Are there any community standards for creating custom HTMLHint rules? Thanks!

title: enforce no self-closing tags with tag-self-close
body:
**Describe the solution you'd like** The [`tag-self-close`](https://github.com/htmlhint/HTMLHint/wiki/Tag-self-close) rule, when true, requires empty tags to be self-closed. When false, this rule does not apply. I would like an option to require tags **not** to be self-closed. `
` should **always** be typed as `
`, `
` as `
`, no self-closing tags for `meta`, `link`, ect. With HTML5 as a standard for the last four years, and self-closing tags being optional in the [spec](https://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/#tags), I feel this is practical to enforce consistent markup. **Describe alternatives you've considered** Simply using `"tag-self-close": false` does not enforce not having closing tags. I've seen numerous code samples that use a mix of self-closed and unclosed tags, which I feel to be sloppy. **Additional context** HTML5 [self-closing tags](https://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/#tags) are optional. If this feature request is approved, all [void elements](https://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/#void-elements-0) (`link`, `meta`, `hr`, `br`, ect) should be able to have no-self-closing enforced on them. There may need to be an exception for [foreign elements](https://dev.w3.org/html5/html-author/#foreign-elements-0) such as svg-related tags.

title: Whitespace inside attribute
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...]
Many times, people add unnecessary whitespaces inside some attributes. For example `class=" col-md-2"` and sometimes double space between values in the `class` attribute `class="col-md-2  col-offset-2`
Would be nice to give a warning in such cases

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Would be good to have a rule for "No leading/training spaces in attribute" and maybe another one specifically for `class` attribute to handle that all values should be separated by a single space

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
NA
